physics.principle: Birefringent crystals split incident light into ordinary ray (o-ray) and extraordinary ray (e-ray)
physics.principle_foundation: Some crystals are like a Y-shaped road for light - one beam goes straight, the other takes a detour. The two beams wiggle in different directions, so you see two separate images!
physics.principle_research: In uniaxial crystals, the dielectric tensor is diagonal with εₓₓ = εᵧᵧ = nₒ² and εᵤᵤ = nₑ². The ordinary ray obeys Snell's law with index nₒ, while the extraordinary ray experiences an effective index n(θ) = nₒnₑ/√(nₒ²sin²θ + nₑ²cos²θ), causing angular separation (walk-off) between the two beams.
details: O-ray and e-ray have perpendicular polarization directions
Different propagation speeds cause phase difference
Calcite is a typical birefringent material

physics.principle: Wave plates introduce controlled phase delay using birefringence

Half-wave plate: δ = π (180°)
Can convert linear to circular polarization or rotate polarization direction
details_foundation: Quarter-wave: delays one part by a quarter turn - makes light spin in circles

physics.principle: Fresnel equations describe reflection and transmission coefficients at interfaces
physics.principle_foundation: When light hits water or glass, some bounces back (reflection) and some goes through (transmission). The steeper you look, the more goes through. The shallower you look, the more bounces back - like skipping stones!
physics.principle_research: Fresnel equations derive from Maxwell's boundary conditions requiring continuity of tangential E and H components. For s-polarization: rs = (n₁cosθᵢ - n₂cosθₜ)/(n₁cosθᵢ + n₂cosθₜ). For p-polarization: rp = (n₂cosθᵢ - n₁cosθₜ)/(n₂cosθᵢ + n₁cosθₜ). The asymmetric response leads to preferential s-polarization in reflected light.
details: S and p polarizations have different reflectances
Total internal reflection critical angle exists
At Brewster's angle, p-polarization reflection is zero
details_foundation: Light bouncing up-down (s) reflects differently than light bouncing side-to-side (p)
At steep angles, most light goes through - water looks clear
At shallow angles, most light bounces - water looks like a mirror
details_research: R_s monotonically increases with angle; R_p has minimum at Brewster's angle
Phase shifts differ: reflected s-wave always π-shifted; p-wave flips sign at Brewster's angle
Ellipsometry exploits the differential response to measure film thickness with nm precision

malus.curveDesc: X-axis: angle θ (0°–180°), Y-axis: transmission ratio I/I₀. Red dot shows current position.
malus.explanation0: Two polarizers are nearly parallel, transmitted intensity ≈ I₀, almost no loss.
malus.explanation90: Two polarizers nearly crossed (90°), transmitted intensity → 0, almost no light.
malus.explanation45: When θ ≈ 45°, cos²θ ≈ 0.5, transmitted intensity is about half of I₀.
malus.explanationOther: As θ increases from 0°→90°, intensity decreases; from 90°→180° it increases again.
malus.tip: Try guessing intensity at θ=0°, 45°, 90° first, then verify by dragging slider.
malus.assumption: Assumes incident light is fully linearly polarized and polarizer is ideal.
malus.malusDesc: When linearly polarized light passes through a polarizer, I = I₀cos²θ.

brewster.title: Brewster's Angle Interactive Demo
brewster.subtitle: tan(θB) = n₂/n₁ — At this angle, reflected light is fully s-polarized
brewster.chartDesc: At Brewster's angle, Rp=0, polarization degree reaches 100% (fully s-polarized).
brewster.brewsterDesc: When incident angle equals Brewster's angle, reflected and refracted are perpendicular, p-pol reflectance is zero.
brewster.physicalDesc: At Brewster's angle, oscillating charges in refracted beam are parallel to reflection direction, cannot radiate effectively.
brewster.dispersionDesc: Refractive index varies with wavelength (dispersion), causing slightly different Brewster angles for different colors. Blue light has higher n than red, so blue has larger Brewster angle. This explains why broadband AR coatings are difficult—cannot satisfy Brewster condition for all wavelengths simultaneously.

opticalRotation.title: Optical Rotation Interactive Demo
opticalRotation.subtitle: α = [α] × c × L — Exploring rotation effect of chiral substances on polarization plane
opticalRotation.principleDesc: Chiral molecules have non-superimposable mirror images, rotating polarization plane. Dextro (d/+) is clockwise, levo (l/-) is counterclockwise.
opticalRotation.specificRotationDesc: [α] is a characteristic constant of the substance, defined as rotation at unit concentration (1 g/mL) and unit path (1 dm). Depends on wavelength and temperature.
